text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

author: Lawrence Of Canadia

text:
Man made climate change.¬† I am still waiting to see some hard data.¬† So far all I ever get to see is some news articles and various government reports.¬† ( I trust neither source)¬† I've never seen the actual numbers for myself.¬† So as far as what the temperature record is I couldn't tell you.¬† The various numbers they do throw around, to me, as a mechanical engineering student (3rd time around for school, I'm old) have a few¬†too many decimal places behind the zero to be considered more than a rounding error.¬† Add up enough rounding errors in the right way and you can get just about any number to move incrementally in the direction you desire.¬†

Now as to the effects of a changing climate, generally that means weather patterns change and water moves.¬† So in other words it gets colder or hotter in various places, and the water either rises or falls.

The general theme is that the water will move upward.¬† Causing flooding displacing people near the ocean.

There are only two kinds of people that live near the waters edge.¬† The very rich (1st world) or the very poor (3rd world) neither group I give a flying flip about.¬† They can move when the ocean comes for them in a few hundred years.

As far as the temperature changing again, where and how much is the important thing, something they have no idea how to do.¬† When I lived in South Dakota, anything in the warmer direction would have been great.¬† When I lived in Southern California in the Mojave desert anything cooler would have been great.¬†

So why do I bag on Al Gore when I am willing to go either way based on the numbers in terms of climate change.¬† Because the man is a bullshit artist.¬† If he actually cared he wouldn't be spending so much time chasing money and more time actually doing something about it.¬†

If you want to see what a man cares about just go see how he lives.¬†¬†A lavish lifestyle without a solar panel in sight?¬†¬†Yeah sure he gives a fart about climate change.¬† He is a corrupt businessman and politian, nothing more nothing less.

You would rightly point out that I said nothing on whether or not we are causing or at least contributing to the climate to change.¬† Yes I do.¬† Do I think it is going to have that great of an impact, no I don't.¬† At least not in the way all the doomsayers proclaim.

The climate changes in cycles and has¬†do so since before time.¬†¬†This might mean some people will benefit from it and some will be¬†hurt.¬† So be it.
author: GeoFry3

text:
¬†@Sternertime¬† Nope the IPCC report is produced by gov't $$$ by people with an agenda.¬† (Power and money)¬†¬†There are a lot of conclusions, but no base data.¬† Also I'd like to point out¬†little things to justify why I am extremely skeptical of the reports.¬†¬†Why would they not post data past 2010 for a 2014 report.¬† Might be they don't like what the numbers report?¬† It's hard to justify budgets when the numbers don't support it.

Like I said before I'd like to see the raw data.¬† Which is tough since supposedly it doesn't exist.¬† (Yet some how they keep coming up with supposedly very accurate reports.)

As far as being a nihilist.¬† I'm a bit pessimistic, but not that much.¬† I have a rational view of the world.¬† So ask and answer these three questions:

1.¬†¬†People living next to the water, did I force them to live there?
2.¬†¬†Are they aware that the bodies of water move over time?
3.¬†¬†Is it my fault if they don't know that bodies of water move over time?

So the answers are No, Maybe, and No.¬† So hence I do not care.¬† I wouldn't intentionally harm someone, but I do not owe them my time, money, or effort to save them from the¬†situation they find themselves in.¬†¬†Their birth into a near water culture/society is not their¬†fault for sure, but neither is it mine.¬†¬†(That goes triple for rich dumbasses building multi-million dollar homes within a stones throw of the water.)¬† That¬†falls under the category of "life is not fair".¬†

Speaking of fairness.¬†¬†To be fair those people near the water care as much about my issues as I do about theirs which is to say...not at all.

Now before you start saying that it is my fault for using carbon based fuels disrupting their way of life¬†I'd like to point out the presidence of using carbon based fuels predates their living next to the beach by oh say 400,000 years.¬† This is hardly a new thing, using/burning carbon¬†fuel.¬† I'd also like to point out that¬†within that same time period the ocean has changed height by nearly 400 feet, first going WAY down, and then WAY back up, so neither are the ocean levels changing a new or even unusual concept.

So other than calling me names and hinting that I have no ethics do you have anything of substance to contribute or was I right with my initial assessment that you have no real knowledge or insight to contribute, just an opinion and or an agenda.

text:
Quite a rousing speech, but there are several glaring, problematic omissions.  Mind you I‚Äôm not disputing climate science here, rather I‚Äôm showing crucial points that counter the narrative that says business as usual, status quo, self-preservation is ‚Äúalready solving the problem.‚Äù

1.  In spite of decades and trillions already spent on renewable energy development, there is still no significant long term decline in the percentage of total energy humanity consumes from fossil fuels.  It is still at 85%, as Gore points out, but he doesn‚Äôt tell you that it‚Äôs been thereabout since record keeping began.  Even more worrying is the fact that economic growth and fossil fuel consumption are still moving upward in lock step.  Something which should be cause for alarm for people who continue to insist that this cancerous growth model is sustainable and necessary.  There is no reliable evidence that this death coupling will permanently separate anytime soon, especially when you consider how all renewables require massive fossil fuel feed stocks that plunge us deeper into the ‚Äúenergy trap‚Äù.
2. The growth rate in wind and solar is expected to flatten out starting in the 2020s as efficiency and cost improvements dry up and scaling difficulties harden.  From about 30% annual increases on installed capacity to about the single digits.  At that rate it could take over a century to power the world with wind and solar.  Time we don‚Äôt have.  Meanwhile, the EIA estimates global energy demand to increase 57% by 2040.  Even the more conservative estimates by the EIA say that by 2040, renewables will account for only 15% of world consumption, compared to 11% in 2010.  Piss poor!
3. Battery technologies based on lithium will suffer their own scaling problems due to scarcity of materials.  Even with more abundant minerals, lead in particular, they are not abundant enough and adding in redundancies for power outages and intermittency will increase costs by several multiples.  Estimates for the cost a global battery infrastructure run into the tens of trillions of dollars.
4. The EROI for most renewables is abysmal compared to fossil fuels.  PV solar is estimated at 5:1 (at best), newer solar concentrators are no more than 10:1.  Researchers argue that we need between 5-9 EROI to maintain our wanton lifestyles.  Effective net gains globally may be much lower.
5. Probably the most deluded assumption is asserting that a ‚Äúgrid parity‚Äù crossover is all that is required for a worldwide turnaround to clean green energy.  The reality is that these changes should have been pursued decades ago, when there wasn‚Äôt a direct financial incentive.  It may already be too late to preserve this civilization for large swaths of people around the world.

Brace yourself‚Ä¶

author: Adrian

text: +Adrian Some countries are already using over 50% of their daily energy needs from solar. Kurzweil's predictions are rarely completely wrong, and they are sometimes somewhat wrong (he doesn't seem to account for social, cultural, economic, political surprise changes, so he can be ~5-10 years off), but change that 2030 to 2040/2050, and change 'solar power' to 'renewables', and its very very very very likely. Panels will eventually be cheap enough for any building to easily set up and the batteries to easily store. They'll be efficient enough to power industry. And that's not counting the other options that are non-solar but still relatively much less impacting of environment.

text: +itoohavedreams The medieval warm period (learn to spell) was most likely a result of increased sunspot activity due to changes in milankovitch cycles. However this cannot explain recent warming which has been happening faster than ever naturally recorded. You quote natural climate oscillations but these happen over a far longer scale (10s of 1000s of years) than what has been seen over the last 200.
author: A L E

text:
+itoohavedreams
"Then ask them what they think about the mid-evil warm period. "
What about it? Northern Europe and Greenland were much warmer and relatively fertile...the rest of the world, not so much. Much of Asia and North America were experiencing mega droughts. The MWP was more than likely primarily a local phenomenon.

"Then ask them what effect the Earth's positioning from the sun has on the temperature."

Depends on the milankovitch factors at play, but the factors you're talking about won't be significant for thousands of years and take tens of thousands if not hundreds of thousands of years. Which is kind of amusing when you're trying to attribute them for the cause of the last few decades.

The proper way to approach the problem is ask what would be predicted patterns of warming based on different mechanisms and test accordingly. We know that CO2 is the most likely cause because it has a unique fingerprint of warming the troposphere while cooling the stratosphere. It has several other fingerprints within the instrumental record, but this unique fingerprint is also within the record and even if you reject CO2 as the cause you still need to explain the observations.
author: garith21

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†Right....Till you realize there are observations that we have on instrumental record this might seem convincing.

We observe more warming at the poles than the equator...probably not the sun doing that.

We observe a warming in the troposphere but a cooling in the stratosphere...again probably not the sun.

We observe the sun it's self has been dimming over the last few solar cycles to the point that people have been questioning whether or not we'll enter a new maunder minimum. Probably not responsible for most of the warming through those solar cycles.

We observe it warming at night at about as much as the day...again probably not the sun.

We measure an increase in downwards long wave radiation in the bands that CO2 absorbs....again probably not the sun.

There are reasons why the scientists discuss topics like most recent decades with regards to this matter because while solar activity has been dropping, temperatures have continued to rise.

Also we're already pretty aware of the brightening of the sun over the last 100-150 years, in fact it explains most of the warming for most of the instrumental record up till a few decades ago which no one disputes.

It doesn't however explain the most recent warming because none of the observations that would be expected for that proposed mechanism are visible.

Also for your 12 year old article I will post the 12 year old statement from the same institute.

https://www.mpg.de/research/sun-influence-global-climate

author: Rolf Li

text:
¬†@misiek7676¬†¬†That would be arbitrary, in general. The issue is that climate is changing at a rapid pace and our infrastructure is based around this general climate. There's also the issue that other organisms also rely on climate being relatively stable or changing relatively slowly (in comparison to today) to evolve rather than going extinct.

Ideally we'd want to keep it under a 2C warming of preindustrial times, though pushing even that 2C range can be pretty bad for us in our current conditions, 2C happens to just be the upper bound before you start reaching situations where it's about as good as a coin flip or worse with regards to us. That is assuming you don't want to replace vast amounts of infrastructure or use vast amount of resources to adjust for the change in fresh water and food production.
author: garith21

text:
¬†@misiek7676¬†
1) Well, different mechanisms have different patterns of how they would warm (or cool) there are several lines of evidence that indicate the primary cause of most of the warming is CO2. If you would like I could go over some of the observations, but I don't want this post to be longer than necessary and I already have a bad habit of being wordy.

We also know that we're the primary cause of most of the CO2 imbalance, particularly over the last half century.

2) Yes, this would be known as mass extinction, there have been a few in the past, but ideally since a lot of our food supply and discoveries are based on these ecosystems even if we just say that we don't care about nature on a ethical basis there's still reason to care for selfish reasons.

Extinction aren't dreadfully uncommon with regards to the geological record, but current rates are around 1,000 times faster than usual background which is why this is starting to be referred to as the 6th mass extinction event. Mass extinctions are very rare when you consider the vast amount of past climate changes in geological history.

3) With regards to? Which Nobel prize winner? Discrepancy with what? Also man made climate change in scientific circles tends to be talked about with regards to the last half century or so because solar forcing can be attributed as the primary cause of most of the warming in the first half of the 20th century, but not so for most of the later half.

As a note this is because our collective forcing rose out of what could be dismissed as natural background variation in the later half of the century, more so in the last few decades or so when temperatures rose independently of solar activity.
